title: [$250] Remove SearchContext from the useOnyx when not needed

labels.name: External
labels.description: Added to denote the issue can be worked on by a contributor

labels.name: Daily
labels.description: KSv2

labels.name: Bug
labels.description: Something is broken. Auto assigns a BugZero manager.

labels.name: AutoAssignerNewDotQuality
labels.description: Used to assign quality issues to engineers

body:
Coming from [this proposal](https://expensify.slack.com/archives/C05LX9D6E07/p1757511640708319) ### Background The useOnyx hook (a wrapper around the original useOnyx) is used throughout the app. Inside it, we subscribe to SearchContext so the hook can return data from either the regular Onyx keys or the special SNAPSHOT keys (which are specifically designed for the Reports page). However, useOnyx hooks that are not used on the Reports page don’t need SearchContext, since they don’t rely on currentSearchHash (which is only used to access the current SNAPSHOT data). ### Problem If SearchContext changes, then every useOnyx in the App will rerender. Such context change will trigger rerenders in screens that are rendered in the history, preloaded screens or modals that live outside of navigation like SearchRouter and can cause massive overhead. ### Solution Avoid useOnyx calls outside the Reports/Search tree from subscribing to SearchContext. How: SearchContext provides components with isOnSearch prop that with the help of SearchScopeProvider tells us if the useOnyx is part of Search/index component tree(is on Reports page). To reduce rerenders, we could: - take isOnSearch prop out of SearchContext and put it in SearchScopeProvider , isOnSearch doesn't trigger rerenders as it is a static prop. - in useOnyx use the new use API to conditionally listen to SearchContext, that way useOnyx hooks that are part of Search/index component tree(this is static) will access SearchContext that they need and useOnyx hooks that don't need it won't rerender. ``` const useOnyx: OriginalUseOnyx = >(key: TKey, options?: UseOnyxOptions, dependencies?: DependencyList) => { const {isOnSearch} = useIsOnSearch(); let currentSearchHash: number | undefined; if (isOnSearch) { const {currentSearchHash: searchContextCurrentSearchHash} = use(SearchContext); currentSearchHash = searchContextCurrentSearchHash; } ... rest of useOnyx hook ... ``` Benefits This will provide big boost to scenarios where SearchContext changes, examples(perf measured on iOS simulator): 1. On Reports page the user changes search type with the search type menu(Submit -> Pay): - OLD: total React work: 7234.014ms - ~55 commits - NEW: total React work: 5357.51 - 48 commits (25%/1877 ms better) 3. After fresh log into the app, user enters Reports page and then goes back to Inbox: - OLD: total React work: 5992.427ms - ~67 commits - NEW: total React work: 4890.688 - 59 commits (18%/1102 ms better)

  • Upwork Job ID: 1965843867509223663
  • Last Price Increase: 2025-09-10
Issue OwnerCurrent Issue Owner: @Pujan92

title: [$250] Add extra logs to the useSidebarOrderedReports hook

labels.name: Reviewing
labels.description: Has a PR in review

labels.name: External
labels.description: Added to denote the issue can be worked on by a contributor

labels.name: Weekly
labels.description: KSv2

labels.name: Bug
labels.description: Something is broken. Auto assigns a BugZero manager.

body:
Coming from [here](https://expensify.slack.com/archives/C05LX9D6E07/p1757427870254749?thread_ts=1756201512.926039&cid=C05LX9D6E07) ### Background The useSidebarOrderedReports hook manages and sorts reports data. It processes large amounts of information, including chat reports, policies, and transactions. The hook includes a logChangedDeps function that tracks dependency changes and logs performance metrics. ### Problem The current measurement only captures the logging overhead via processingDuration, not the actual data processing time. As a result, we lack visibility into how expensive this hook is during renders, making it difficult to detect or diagnose performance regressions. ### Solution Enhance the logging in useSidebarOrderedReports by: - Measuring the actual execution time of the hook’s data processing logic. - Tracking component usage alongside corresponding render durations.

title: [$250] Forbid inline useOnyx selectors

labels.name: External
labels.description: Added to denote the issue can be worked on by a contributor

labels.name: Daily
labels.description: KSv2

labels.name: Bug
labels.description: Something is broken. Auto assigns a BugZero manager.

labels.name: AutoAssignerNewDotQuality
labels.description: Used to assign quality issues to engineers

body:
coming from [this proposal](https://expensify.slack.com/archives/C05LX9D6E07/p1757428589519799) ### Background Selectors in react-native-onyx are functions that allow to subscribe a subset of data from storage, providing performance benefits by only re-rendering components when the selected data changes, rather than when any property in the entire object changes. They transform, filter, or extract specific data and support type-safe operations on both individual keys and collections. Recently we merged a couple of improvements to useOnyx, including the memoization working properly with stable references. However, most of our codebase still uses inline selectors, which prevents us from taking advantage of these optimizations. ### Problem When using selectors in useOnyx, if you define the selector as inline function directly in the options object, then the memoization system breaks causing unnecessary re-computations and re-renders on every component update. ### Solution Make selectors first-class citizens in E/App by organizing them according to their usage scope: - Shared selectors: if a selector is reused across multiple components, define it in a dedicated selectors/ directory so it can be consistently imported and reused. - Local selectors: if a selector exists purely for the needs of a single component or hook, define it in the same file outside the component where it’s used to avoid unnecessary abstraction. - Contextual selectors: if a selector relies on additional data from the component itself, define it as a useCallback inside the component, with the relevant data passed as dependencies.

body:
If you haven’t already, check out our [contributing guidelines](https://github.com/Expensify/ReactNativeChat/blob/main/contributingGuides/CONTRIBUTING.md) for onboarding and email contributors@expensify.com to request to join our Slack channel! ___ **Version Number:** v9.2.8-1 **Reproducible in staging?:** Yes **Reproducible in production?:** No **If this was caught during regression testing, add the test name, ID and link from TestRail:** https://github.com/Expensify/App/pull/68929 **Email or phone of affected tester (no customers):** N/A **Issue reported by:** Applause Internal Team **Device used:** Windows 11 / Chrome, Chrome / Xiaomi Poco F5, macOS 14.5 / MacBook Air 2020, Android 13 / Xiaomi Poco F5, iOS 15.8.3 / iPhone 7 Plus **App Component:** Other ## Action Performed: Precondition: - Have at least a workspace 1. Go to workspace chat and create two expenses 2. Create an empty report 3. Go to Reports > Expenses tab 4. Select one expense using checkbox and hold the expense 5. Verify that the "This expense was put on hold" will appear 6. Select another expense using checkbox and move the expense to the empty report from step 2 7. Verify that the "This expense was put on hold" also appears on the moved expense ## Expected Result: The error message "This expense was put on hold" should not appear on the moved expense ## Actual Result: The error message "This expense was put on hold" appear on the moved expense Note: - The error "This expense was put on hold" will disappear after user open the moved expenses ## Workaround: Unknown ## Platforms: - [x] Android: App - [x] Android: mWeb Chrome - [x] iOS: App - [x] iOS: mWeb Safari - [x] iOS: mWeb Chrome - [x] Windows: Chrome - [x] MacOS: Chrome / Safari - [x] MacOS: Desktop ## Screenshots/Videos https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/7688b1bc-7407-4bdb-aabc-85d31227fc19 [View all open jobs on GitHub](https://github.com/Expensify/App/issues?q=is%3Aopen+is%3Aissue+label%3A%22Help+Wanted%22)

body:
If you haven’t already, check out our [contributing guidelines](https://github.com/Expensify/ReactNativeChat/blob/main/contributingGuides/CONTRIBUTING.md) for onboarding and email contributors@expensify.com to request to join our Slack channel! ___ **Version Number:** 9.2.3-2 **Reproducible in staging?:** Y **Reproducible in production?:** Y **If this was caught during regression testing, add the test name, ID and link from TestRail:** https://test-management.browserstack.com/projects/2219752/folder/13176725/test-cases/41237073 **Issue reported by:** Applause - Internal Team ## Action Performed: Preconditions: two accounts needed - User A and User B, have never interacted before 1. Sign in to ND with both users 2. User A, start a chat with User B, send a message 3. User B, do not open the chat, verify that the chat is bold in LHN and shows a new message 4. User A, create an expense in the chat with User B 5. User B, observe the LHN - the chat is not bold 6. User B, open the chat - new message line does not appear above the unread message, sent before the expense ## Expected Result: Unread chat stays bold in LHN after an expense is received. The new message line is displayed above the unread message ## Actual Result: Unread chat is not bold in LHN after an expense is received. The new message line is not displayed above the unread message ## Workaround: Unknown ## Platforms: Select the officially supported platforms where the issue was reproduced: - [ ] Android: App - [ ] Android: mWeb Chrome - [ ] iOS: App - [ ] iOS: mWeb Safari - [ ] iOS: mWeb Chrome - [x] Windows: Chrome - [x] MacOS: Chrome / Safari - [ ] MacOS: Desktop
